On Jan 2, 2012, at 1:05 PM, Jorn Wildt wrote:

> > or we define (in the li=
nked ontology spec or somewhere else; ideally
> > globally) what is the mea=
ning of each of the fixed set of operations
> > (GET/PUT/POST/DELETE) for e=
ach concept.
> 
> > This is not usually defined by a media type
> 
> Sorry,=
 but isn't that exactly what is supposed to be defined by a media type? See=
 for instance http://bitworking.org/projects/atom/rfc5023.html#collection_r=
esource where POST/PUT/DELETE is defined for AtomPub
> 

Yes, correct. Or m=
ore exactly: HTTP methods mean the same thing regardless of context (unifor=
m interface). Resource semantics (the stuff you learn about resources from =
hypermedia references) is what is defined in media types (or link relation =
specs).

Media types ideally do not specify what methods to use for resourc=
es with certain semantics. That would be an over-specification because it i=
s up to the server to make these decisions (and change them anytime).

Medi=
a type specs however can fruitfully provide hints to the canonical/intended=
 use cases that informed the design of the media type in the first place. S=
HOULD requirements often reflect that and inform server developers about th=
e most sensible implementation choices.

What you can specifiy in media typ=
es is which method a user agent developer should use for the implementation=
 of a control (e.g. GET on HTML <a> links or <img>es, POST/GET for <form>s,=
 depending on action parameter, etc. But there is no guarantee (aka couplin=
g) that the server will actually support that message. (It should of course=
, because it sent the previous hypermedia in the first place :-)

If a requ=
est fails, HTTP provides error codes to hint the client how to fix its own =
configuration to match a particular service's implementation. This is an as=
pect that is unlikely to change and likely needs only be adjusted once per =
live time of the service.
(BTW, this IMHO indicates a conceptual third 'xxx=
-time' between design-time and run-time. You might think of it as 'introspe=
ction time' or 'configuration time'. OPTIONS requests relate to this. Nice =
area for research, IMO).

> This seems more and more like re-inventing the =
exact reason for having media types - but hiding/tunneling it inside some g=
eneric format like application/xml.
> 

Yes, exactly.

> You are right in t=
he way that, yes, it can be done. But there should be no need for it when t=
he same thing can be done with a properly defined media type.

Actually, st=
rictly speaking there is no need for this in the media type either.

> 
> I=
f you build your application on top of HTTP, using it only for transport of=
 data and using only predefined domain-agnostic formats like application/xm=
l, then, yes, you would have to put the domain specific semantics "somewher=
e else".

Yes, exactly.

> 
> If, on the other hand, you accept HTTP as an =
application protocol, then you can use the media type for defining your sem=
antics.

Yes.

> 
> But, apparently there are different views of HTTP as an=
 application protocol or a simple data transfer layer?

In my experience, i=
t is still very common that people try to bend REST in order to match their=
 view of a problem - instead of bending their view of the problem to make s=
ense from a REST POV. Such bent-versions ('views' in your sentence) of REST=
 are not necessarily bad, but they are not REST as it has been defined[1]. =
This can sometimes make approaching REST more confusing as it already usual=
ly is.

Jan
